title: Protocol for live-cell imaging during Tumor Treating Fields treatment with Inovitro Live
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Setting up Inovitro LiveTM
Timing: 30 min
In the following steps, all procedures that have to be performed prior to the start of an experiment are discussed
Place the Ibidi dish with cells and the sterile Inovitro LiveTM insert (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F) in a clean biological hood.
Place the Ibidi Glass cover (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D) on the Inovitro LiveTM insert.
Insert the Inovitro LiveTM insert onto the Ibidi dish
Press down firmly until the insert reaches the bottom (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Stage Top Chamber: Make sure that silicone tubing (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B) is in place for medium replacement.
Cooling Coil: Make sure that cooling coil is in place.
Transfer the Ibidi dish with insert horizontally and place it on the microscope stage.
Fix it to the stage firmly using a designated connector or glue pads.
Connect the Inovitro LiveTM cable (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C) to the insert (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Place the cover heating element over the Inovitro LiveTM insert (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Connect CO2 gas supply to the microscope chamber.
Switch on the generator and laptop.
Open the Inovitro LiveTM software.
Note: In this protocol, the microscope chamber is assembled by combining an Okolab H101-K-Frame in conjunction with the Okolab H101-2x35-M insert for 35 mm petri dishes. Although this combination guarantees the Inovitro LiveTM setup to fit in the microscope chamber, other microscope chambers with a minimum chamber height of 30 mm may be used.
Using Inovitro LiveTM software
Timing: 5 min
In the following steps, all options and functions in the InoVitro LiveTM software (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]) are explained.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1524-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Inovitro LiveTM software

A view of the software that is used to control the Inovitro LiveTM setup, depicting the main screen (A); panel to change parameter settings (B); ongoing experiment screen displaying all dish parameters (C); graphs of log files over time (D).
Create a new experiment by pressing the ‘New Experiment’ button (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
In the pop-up window, the experiment name, owner, and a short description can be filled in.
Use only regular characters (letters and numbers) for experiment name and owner
Disable the “configure session” option.
Set the desired parameters correctly (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
The frequency of TTFields can be applied between 50 to 500 kHz.
E.g., U251 is treated with 200 kHz.
Medium target temperature can be set between 20°C to 40°C.
Cover heating element temperature can be set between 37°C to 55°C.
Duty cycle A and B represent the frequency of switching between TTFields directions. Set either A or B to ‘0’ to apply TTFields from a single pair of electrodes.
Adjust alarm thresholds by pressing the ‘Change Default’ button.
If the medium temperature exceeds the set value, an alarm will be displayed.
While the experiment is running (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C), the following values will be displayed:
Frequency
Target temperature
Temperature (2×)
Cover Temperature
Current (2×)
Resistance (2×)
Vout
During an experiment, log graphs (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D) can be requested by pressing the ‘reports’ button.
Start & end TTF treatment
Timing: Dependent on experimental setup
Set the treatment settings using the Inovitro LiveTM software and start the experiment.
Depending on the cooling strategy:
Stage top incubator: Set the temperature of the stage top incubator to the desired value, ranging from 18°C-32°C, with lower temperatures leading to higher TTFields intensities.

Cooling coil: Start the peristaltic pump at the lowest speed and allow the medium temperature to stabilize. Gradually increase the pump speed until desired current is reached.
To prevent disruption of flow of the peristaltic pump:
Check if the silicone tubing is firmly placed in the pump.
Check if no connections between the silicone tubing are leaking.
Make sure the cold water inflow tubing is not blocked.
Meanwhile, position the dish with cells at the region-of-interest and select the desired microscope settings (channels, exposure times etc.) using the microscope software.
Follow the experiment for 20–30 min until the medium temperature has stabilized and, if necessary, adjust the focus of the microscope as temperature changes can affect focusing.
To end the experiment, press the stop experiment button in the software (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Allow time for all data to be transferred from the generator to the laptop/computer.
Turn off the generator and disconnect all cables from the insert.
Remove the Inovitro liveTM insert from the dish by pulling vertically.
Rinse the insert thoroughly with distilled water and let dry.
Sterilize the insert in an autoclave before the next experiment.
Optional: When using a stage top incubator in experiments that last longer than 24 h, the medium has to be replaced daily.
Connect a sterile 5 mL syringe to the silicone tubing (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Pause the experiment by clicking the pause button in the software (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Remove the medium using the syringe.
Carefully inject 3 mL new medium with a new, sterile syringe.
Note: The cover heating element can become warm. To avoid skin burns, only touch it after sufficient cooling time (>1 min.) after turning off the system.
Note: The slightest movement of the dish could impede cell tracking during long experiments. Make sure you are not putting any tension on the dish, cables, or silicone tubing.
